Forum To
Academic
Students, faculty, and administration are scheduled to meet
next Tuesday in a forum sponsored by the Academic Affairs
Committee of the Student Council. The forum, which will begin
at 4 p.m. in the Garrett Room
of the Eisenhower Library, will
be open to all members of the
Hopkins academic community.
The forum is to be held for
the purpose of evaluating the
progress of the Administration
in responding to the Report of
the Undergraduate Committee
for Curriculum Studies, submitted last spring by undergraduates Robert Bittick and Robert
Butler. The report dealt in
length with the issues of departmental autonomy, course offerings, basic degree requirements,
faculty teaching, and the advising system.
Administration Response
As a direct result of suggestions made in the report, the
position of Dean of Undergraduate Studies was formed. As the
next step, a major increase in
faculty is planned, beginning
possibly next semester, to provide for a greater selection of
ccsirses. With this accomplished,
a plan to liberalize degree requirements will be instituted to
permit breadth as well as depth
In studies.

History Course on
Jobs Availa5le
'eview
American Negro
Policy To Be Offered
For Work-Study

Among those members of the
faculty and administration who
will serve on the forum panel
are Robert Strider, Associate
Dean for Administration, Dr.
Carl Swanson, Assistant Dean
for Undergraduate Studies, and
Dr. Stephen Ambrose, associate
professor of history. Bittick and
Butler will act as student representatives on the panel.
Action and Reaction
Butler will open the forum
with a statement summarizing
the report's goals, after which
Dean Swanson will explain what
action has been taken thus far.
Following Dean Swanson's remarks, other members of the
panel will be invited to speak,
after which will ensue a general
discussion period.
According to Mark Steinberg,
a junior student council representative and a member of its
Academic Affairs Committee, the
forum is the first of Several to
be held this year. Future discussions may center on such
topics as calendar reform, passfail grading, and a tutorial program. The success of the open
forum and its future use, he indicated, will depend largely on
the turn-out of the students, for
whose benefit it is being held.

Choral Society Bills
Mozart for Premier
Mozart's Requiem of 1791 and
the 30th Ode of Solomon by
American composer Alan Hoyhaness will open the Hopkins
Choral Society's second season
of concerts.
The works will be performed
on Sunday, January 8, at 3:30
p.m. in Shriver Hall.
Admission to the concert directed by Nelson Sweglar is free
and open to the entire public
through the financial assistance
of the Musical Performance
Trust Fund.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 16, 1966

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

The Department of History
will offer a course in Negro History during the second semester.
The course, entitled "The Negro
in America", will be taught by
Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick,
member of the faculty of Coppin State College in Baltimore.
According to Dr. Reddick, the
course will start with an African
background . and move to the
present. There will be special
emphasis on the aspects of Negro
History that have influenced the
growth of the American Republic, The point of view will be
economic, political, and cultural.
The course is presently scheduled for Thursday at 9-11 with
a conference hour to be included. In addition, it will probably
be limited to advanced undergraduates and graduates.

Ph.D at Chicago
Dr. Reddick graduated magna
cum laude from Fisk University
and received his Ph.D. at the
University of Chicago. He has
taught at Kentucky State College, Dillard University, Atlanta
University, Alabama State College and Coppin State College.
He was also a part-time lecturer
at New York City College and
the New School for Social Research.
He is the author of numerous
books and articles including,
with
Our Cause Speeds On
Crusader
Sherman
Savage),
Without Violence, A Biography
of Martin Luther King, and Our
Colleges and the Industrialization of the South. His articles
have appeared in The Nation,
The New Republic, Journal of
Negro Education and Journal of
Negro History.
Research on Inner-City
During 1965-66, he directed a
project, under a U.S. Office of
Education grant, designed to
improve the education of teachers for inner-schools. Presently
he is involved in the training of
community leaders and staffs
for establishing motivational and
skill centers for economically
disadvantaged peoples throughout the nation,

Loves Barber
To the Editors:
I was delighted to learn in
The News-Letter (Dec. 9) of the
fair and amioable solution to the
Marylander Barber Shop dispute,
and the forthright manner in
which it was resolved. Mr. De
Ruggiero will find three new
regular year round customers
among the Hartman family who
have never patronized the shop
previously. I hope other members of the local community, and
especially those affiliated with
the Hopkins. will also give the
shop the special attention it deserves.
Philip E. Hartman
Professor of Biology

Elections Attacked
To the Editors:
Here Is the ultimate trivia
question of the year:
It is not what was the name
of Ida Lupino's dog in "High
Sierra". It is not the name of
the lady living across the hall
from Gale Storm in "My Little
Margie". It's not even the name
of the Ombudsman of Sweden.
That's right, Mark and Dennis ..... the question is, what
occurred last Tuesday and Wednesday?

one lonely sign announcing the

"How did you find out about
this?" We wonder too!

notice of the availability of petitions was placed in three central
locations—the Gilman post office, the bank-bookstore area,
dorm mail room. Whatever the
complaints, ten candidates did
manage to present themselves for
election. This is quite a respectable turnout for an off year
election.

Forum Letter
Among the rumors floating around concerning the
University's new president, there is the one which claims
that his experience and future efforts will be found to
lie primarily in the academic sphere of education. With
the completion of a successful, if aesthetically unnerving,
building program under Dr. Eisenhower, the argument
runs, it is now time to focus on the essential justification
for the expanded physical plant, namely, the quality of
education at Hopkins.
Whether or not the new president will, in fact, be
oriented in this direction, the rumor is symptomatic
of a frame of mind which does presently exist among
iidministration and faculty. Plans to increase faculty,
offer more courses, and broaden degree requirements
&re major innovations long needed and soon to be
effected. In passing, we might note that unfortunate rejection by the Academic Council of any sort of pass-fail
grading system.
The forum next Tuesday will give undergraduates
die opportunity to question the powers that he concerning these plans, and the chance to voice whatever
dissatisfactions they may have with the current system.
To this end, we hope that members of the forum panel
other than the principal speakers will keep their comments brief, as with not the case at the last such
gathering.

Now that it is Friday and in
two days the Baltimore Civic
Center is giving us THE BIG

all (I hope to God, all) all be
there to see: THE TEMPTATATIONS! cyns! REDDING!
and MARTHA & THE V.D's! it
seems a good time to reflect upon
the state of popular music and
to draw some pertinent relationships between it (the state of
that) to society. American society in the larger, ugly sense,
Which are, in short, that one is
the microcosm and one is the
macrocosm of the same set of
phenomena, which phenomena
all point to the fact that the
white race, now weak and fleshy
with sloth and money, is no
longer of use to Nature and is
about to be done away with. Extinguished. We are witnessing
the Decline, soon to be the Fall,
of the pink people.
Listen to the radio. Compare
WCAO (where Pat Boone and
Frank Sinatra reside) to WWIN
(the Home of Soul) and tell me
how we can survive. (We, I being
white). Can a race that snaps
its fingers to STRANGERS IN
THE NIGHT compare to one
that goes epileptic to READY
FOR LOVE by Martha and the
girls? Don't be rediculous, Where
is the vitality, the throbbing
life, of LADY GODIVA by that
(some) English group, or Herman's Hermits. You can't build

a culture on novelty songs! Or
on advertisements—notice that
WCAO plays approx. 6 songs an
hour. This is no accident. The
people who listen to it don't
mind. They don't care about the
intensity of emotion or the galvanizing effect upon the body of
DRUMS — those people want
background sound, Muzac, something to obliterate thought as
they walk around the house
dusting, or travel from chair to
chair in the day's odyssey to bed.
They don't want to feel good,
they just want to feel full, and
they take the radio in like potatoes, for filling that's cheap and
easy. I mean does anybody
listen to WINCHESTER CATHEDRAL? How long are they

white America? (call to action:
there'll be dancin indo streets,

singing bank ads and the rhyming loan company ads.
The Viet Nam war. Now, here's
a point of comparison. When a
society involves itself in a tremendous, earthshaking and universally important action, all
levels of that society are concerned, and they consequently
attempt to deal with the aspects
of that action which most affect
them in those forms of art and
communication which most occupy them. Ergo: America deals

in rock and roll. But how?
Which attitude suggests more
realistic (survivalistic) attitudes,
Pat Boone'a opus (name of

their baby
Those people have

Dancing will graduate to spasm,

By PETER KOPER
Andrew Wyeth is out of it. Museum
Curators, art critics, and art students—
the dictators of our modern mass culture — tell us that he has received the
death sentence for artists; he is not
in the mainstream of the modern art
movement.
The hip among the art followers don't
dig him. He's old. And worst of all he
is nostalgic, almost historical.
And look at his pictures. He really
Is out of it. Sam Hunter, a professor
of art and spokesman for the New York
school of art, or what is called the
Abstract Expressionist movement, tells
116 that "in. view of the achievements
Of the Abstract Expressionists in the
fifties it is no longer possible to assume
that the opposing currents of realism,

ularly pails, houses, shacks, fences,
weeds, grass, boats, his wife, the surrounding neighbors, dogs, and snowstorms. He attacks his limited world
with the gusto of a Thomas Wolfe with
blinders. "The wealth of things around
us for an artist to see is just unbelievable. To see it and clarify it in my own
mind. That is the thing," Wyeth comments on his choice of subjects.
And, indeed, this is the key to his
approach, to his philosophy, to his
art, and to his attraction of an admiring public. Wyeth simply paints and
simply lives. His painting forces the
intensificiation of common objects to the
point of realizing that they are a part
of him. He lives his paintings.
Existential Virtue
Existential virtue, That is what his
art is. He describes the existence of an
object and then derives its essence.
"All I know is that I'm not a realist
at all," claims Wyeth, trying to escape
the tag placed on him by the taxonomists of art. And he isn't. If anything
he is an abstract painter, chiefly because of the strength of his compositions. Take a look at That Gentleman,
or Racoon, or even Christina's World.
Asymetrical design and balanced focus,
space and clutter.
Colors Noted
His paintings conjure up the ghosts
of Winslow Homer or John Singer Sergeant or Frederick Remington. But look
at his colors. For the wide range of
tone contrasted with the limited scale
of hue he can be compared with Titian
or Bellini. His use of a low key in
his paintings can be seen in the Potato
Eaters by Van Gogh or The Studio by
Daumier. Anybody can play this game.

'

In one picture, The Children's Doctor,
a portrait of a Johns Hopkins graduate,
he is a surrealist. As a matter of fact
one could compare it favorably with
Dail's Gala. Her Room is another of
Wyeth's creations which makes you
wonder whether he ever fooled with

Wyeth's earlier period of undisciplined

After his father, an illustrator of

of the white cloth coining out of the
shadow of the interior of the porch is
stunning.

In his landscapes, Wyeth uses a style

at a distance, and then move in for a
closer examination. Rather than layering his paint, he deals a great part,of
the time with shadows and perspective,
creating his magic textures painstakingily.
Wyeth's colors do their work in

By 311:RRAY :RUDNICK
Nostalgia. "Andy* Wyeth's paintings
remind me of my childhood. And then I
think how my little Betty Jean will never
see days like I saw. That makes me sad,"
says one woman. And that makes every
Woman in America ,sad. They love the
paintings, but the paintings make them
sad. NO! No! No! Yes, Wyeth is all nostalgia, but certainly anything but sad.
Andrew Wyeth draws his subjects from
four square miles of Pennsylvania and
an even smaller portion of Maine. In
the summer he is instantaneously transported from Chadds Ford to Cushing. In
the winter back to Chadds Ford. He has
never been anywhere else. As a result,
he has held a very tight focus on his
narrow surroundings. And in these surroundings there is only solitude and
stillness. But this solitude is not sadness, it is life held in low key. A slowing
down of one's perceptions in order to
capture a sharper view of time and
sequence.
It is mood that concerns Wyeth, not
tone, as the Impressionists sought, nor
realism, which everyone scorns. Wyeth
takes a moment, reacts to it many
times, and uses highly skilled methods
to translate through intensification that
moment. This is not illustration; it is
skilled perception and interpretation.

even more skill and effort in Wyeth
Form. Subliminal reaction to mood and
scene is transformed into light and
shadow. Light that obscures line and
shadow that obscures line to transcend
image and stand what is perceived apart
from our perception of it.
Do not confuse sentimentality with
vivid apprehension. Wyeth really understands existence, and makes beautiful
things. His critics do not.
A word for beauty?

Lengthy Dissent
Hilites Dullness;

By GERALD BRECHER
Andrew Wyeth's, traveling exhibition
has arrived at the Baltimore Museum.
(That's just south of the campus, engineers.) It seems more than just coincidental that the advent of snow and
cold weather accompanied the advent
of Wyeth, for Wyeth is without a doubt
the epitome of 'cool' in art. Wyeth is
the champion of the anti-modernists,
those would be art lovers whose hope
for the future of art is some sort of
restoration of a fantasied past.

ALBERT'S SON
It is this skill that Wyeth's accusers
lack. Since Duchamps' "Nude Descending a Staircase" at the infamous Armory
Show, laziness has triumphed. Artists
cannot bother to take the time to acquire talent: there is much philosophy
to pursue. Yes, too many ideas and not
much patience. Dropping balloons of red
paint from a rooftop and attaching discarded urinals to wormwood boards
leaves the artist little time to play with
brushes.

The catalogue notes make a big deal
about the fact that Wyeth restricts
his subjects to that which can be found
in close proximity to Chadds Ford, Pa.
or Cushing Maine, the artists two home
grounds. The false simplicity that this
view of life affords leads then to
Wyeth's ability to wash out all colour
from his work, covering all his canvas
with a bland serum of detachment.
A great deal has been made of
Wyeth's attachment for 'nostaligia' as
the essential ingredient of his work.
The detachment that his technique affords him serves most effectively to
bring this nostalgia to the fore. His portrait, The Patriot .(is this an anagram
on Wyeth's part?) is certainly senti-

Realism is nice, I suppose, but it's
more than just old hat. It's dull. Realism
with imagination is hard to achieve
without a certain measure of genius,
and apparently all the realistic genius
went out with the Rennaissance. But
Wyeth will try, I suppose. He does, aftes
all, have an immense amount of artistic
talent. But this is really quite dull,
and his work, for all its bravura effects,
Its so evident competence, is not terribly exciting. And it would seem that
Wyeth is then rejecting the whole point
to modern art, which is exciting, baby.
You know, turned on and all that.
Wyeth is - well - turned off.
I am not convinced by volumes of
prose about the man's sensitivje perception, his apprehension of 'the moment', his intense feeling for the minute instant of life. The effect is of
well polished illustration. It dulls the
mind. One can scarcely wait to leave
the exhibit. They're all the same, these
grey
and
boring
paintings. Life
evidently is a great burden to Wyeth.
Wyeth, evidently is a great burden to
me. Some call it art. Some don't.

Wyeth, you know, is de rigeur among
all sorts of beautiful people, and when
you see this exhibit — if you know anything about the beautiful people — you
can see why. If you really dug the old
Herald Tribune, think Doyle Dane ads
clever, and really go for the old tweed
and heather bit, then Andrew Wyeth is
your man. Understated sophistication
is the key to Wyeth, a sort of grey wash
over all his work. Each painting is a
kind of nether world portrait. The
paintings, have a curious weary quality,
one might almost call it smug.

Skill is out. Beauty is out. Color and
form still exist, but without discipline.
BUT discipline is out, for that requires
time and effort (God forbid!).

We can admit that his technique is
perhaps faultless in its concentration
on detail — there is no living painter
who does grass quite so well as Wyeth.
As a matter of fact, Wyeth's work often
reminds one of that of another eminent
American illustrator, Norman Rockwell.
The painstaking realism evident in both
Rockwell and Wyeth, the sentimentality
that can only be described as heart
rending, the pseudo-condescending taste
for 'humble' nature for their subject
matter — the similarities are quite
definite. The only difference I suppose
is that Rockwell is not quite so pretentious in his presentation. Honest — you
could really find yourself looking for
that stenciled signature of Rockwells
on just about every work in the Wyeth
Exhibit.

"I protest," says the staunch antiWyeth man."There is skill and effort in
abstract form. And philosophy." And

other people of narrow tastes will object to this as an unappreciative re-

spent his youth (never went to school)
learning how to see and draw and paint?
Learning to appreciate his medium?

sponse to some sort of `truly great'

these pictures, being so much a product
of what was probably an adolescent
yearning for a re-birth of Romantic
English portraiture — Reynolds and
the like — are not really more than
deftly turned reproductions. The portraits are over glamorized — this in a
strange way, for most are of unglamourous subjects; Negroes, poor fishermen and the like. But this is part of
the whole 'slumming' attitude that
Wyeth takes toward his artistic view.

His landscapes are equally washed
out. He does have quite the competent
technique with off-white paint. His
greys are quite neatly manipulated —
he knows this, for in each painting is
practically the same tired formula: a
substantial hunk of weathered wall, lots
of carefully painted grass, perhaps a
patch of grey — not bluesea, a bit of
the same coloured sky: Oh Wyeth! Must
you pick every boring moment in nature
and threw it at the culture vultures?
Must everything be low-keyed, washed
out and DRAB?

Dorm Rules
Colonel J. Robert Serena, Head
Resident Counselor of the dormitories, announced last week that
the rule requiring that the door
must remain open at least 450
when one couple is in the room
in the upperclass dorms had
been rescinded by Dean of Students, William K. Morrill.
The ruling will henceforth require that the door be kept open
at a "discretionary distance." It
applies to upperclass dorm residents only.
This discretionary distance
will be left up to the presidents
of the various upperclass dorms,
but it has been made very clear
for the residents that post cards
Will not be allowed.
The new policy is a return to
the way the ruling had read in
years prior to 1965-66. It is
hoped that this will encourage
students to live in the dormitories rather than off campus facilities.

loans, scholarship grants, you

boxes.

obtain it, should pick up the
necessary applications in the
financial aid office, 108 Maryland Ave.

'TIS THE SEASON TO BE JOLLY
I know how busy you are—studying,going to class,helping old grads find their dentures after Homecoming—but,
hark, the Yuletide is almost upon us and it's time we
turned our thoughts to Christmas shopping.
We'll start with the hardest gift problem of all: what to
give the man who has everything. Well sir, here are some
things I'll bet he doesn't have: 1) A dentist's chair. 2) A
Mach number. 3) A street map of Perth, Australia. 4)
Fifty pounds of chicken fat. 5) A pack of Personna Super
Stainless Steel Blades.
"What?" you exclaim, your eyebrows leaping in wild
incredulity. "The man who has everything doesn't have
Personna Super Stainless Steel Blades? What arrant nonsense!" you scoff, making a coarse gesture.
But I insist. The man who has everything doesn't have
Personna because everyone in the dorm is always borrowing them. And small wonder! Wouldn't you be there with
an empty razor and a supplicating sidle if you heard somebody had super-blades that were super-sharp and superdurable; that scrape not, neither do they nick; that shave
you easily and breezily, quickly and slickly, scratchlessly
and matchlessly; that come both in Double-Edge style and
Injector style? Of course you would!
So here is our first gift suggestion. If you know a man
who shaves with Personna, give him a safe.
Next let us take up the thorny problem of buying gifts
when you have no money. Well sir, there are many wonderful gifts which cost hardly anything. A bottle of good
clear water,for example,is always welcome. A nice smooth
rock makes a charming paperweight. In fact, one Christmas back in my own college days, these are exactly the
gifts I gave a beauteous coed named Norma Glebe. I took
a rock, a bottle of water, a bit of ribbon, and attached a
card with this tender sentiment:
Here's some water
And here's a rock.
I love you,daughter,
Around the clock.
Norma was so moved, she seized the rock, smashed the
bottle, and plunged the jagged edge into my sternum.

Here now is a lovely gift for an American History major
—a bronze statuette of Millard Fillmore with a clock in
the stomach. (Mr. Fillmore, incidentally, was the only
American president with a clock in his stomach. James K.
Polk had a stem-winder in his head and William Henry
Harrison chimed the quarter-hour, but only Mr. Fillmore
of all our chief executives had a clock in his stomach.
Franklin Pierce had a sweep second hand and Zachary
Taylor had 17 jewels and Martin Van Buren ticked but, I
repeat, Mr. Fillmore and Mr. Fillmore alone had a clock
in his stomach. Moreover,Mr.Fillmore was the first president with power steering. No wonder they called him
"Old Hickory!")
But I digress. Returning to Christmas gifts, here's one
that's sure to please—a gift certificate from the American
Society of Chiropractors. Accompanying each certificate
is this fetching little poem:
Merry Christmas, Happy New Year,
Joyous sacro-iliac!
May your spine forever shine,
Blessings on your aching back!
May your lumbar ne'er grow number,
May your backbone ne'er dislodge,
May your caudal never dawdle,
Joyeux Noel! Heureux massage!
* * *

Undebatable, however, is that
the size of the most conservative
group of Southern Democrats
has been declining. The New Republic's measures show a decline
from sixty in 1948 to fifty in
1956 and forty in 1964. The Congressional Quarterly's analysis
showed 74 in 1959 and only 50
In 1965.
This trend was somewhat reversed in 1966, especially in the
replacement of some conservatives by liberals, instead of by
conservative Republicans. Six of
the twelve Southern Democrats
(not including the more publicized and more moderate Charles
Weltner of Atlanta) in the last
Congress who could be called liberals will not be returning.
In the North, by the crude use
of crude poll data, it can be said
that the Congressional parties
agree on somewhere between
twenty and forty per cent of the
major issues. In Alabama and
Mississippi it is between seventy
and eighty per cent. Still in at
least the urban areas of the
South there is now a two-party
system even more developed than
that in the urban North.
The parties are basically divided on a liberal-conservative
continuum, but there is some
overlap, especially with conservative Democrats, and the centers of gravity of the parties are
toward the center. Business conservativism has provided the urban two-party system.
Unfortunately, the rural South
Is still dominated by racism, and
has been left far less developed
than the predominantly oneparty rural North, for in
1966 it returned solidly to its
traditional one party, the racist
Democrats,

The Bullets have lost to Albright and nationally-ranked LaSalle by 68-58 and 103-67 counts,
but have subdued Western Maryland 71-50. Competing in the
University Division of the Middle Atlantic Conference, they
usually schedule tougher opposition than does Hopkins.
The Jays who have not beaten
Gettysburg since 1952, are tonight trying to halt a fourteen
game losing streak to tonight's
visitors.
Pacing the Pennsylvania team
in scoring are its two guards,
6-0 senior Steve Satir and 5-10
junior, Rick Falk, who hit for 20
and 18 points respectively in the
Western Maryland contest.
A rugged front line consisting
of 6-5 senior captain Ray Faczan
and two upcomers from '65-66's
18-3 frosh team, 6-2 Tom Houser
and 6-3 Paul Trojak, provides the
Bullets with plenty of board
strength and is likely to be their
big advantage over Hopkins.

take third straight, 67-66.

Natators Out To Stun
Garnets in Opener
By JEFF LAUREN
Looking forward to its most
successful season ever, the varsity swiming team opens its season 3 p.m. tomorrow afternoon
here against Swarthmore.
Knowing that the Garnets expect an easy victory, the tankmen hope to surprise Swarthmore with Hopkins strongest
team in its three year history.
Coach Klarner has been holding
grueling workouts the past week
in anticipation for tomorrow's
meet, which may be an indicator

Three Jays
Win Berths
On 'Star Ten
Three Hopkins hooters were
named to the Mason Dixon Conference 1966 soccer all-star team
this week.
Selected for the first team
were goalie Mike Avery (soph)
and lineman Pablo Drobny (senior). Back Ogden Hamilton (senior) was selected to the second
team.
Varsity soccer captain Drobny
was also. selected to the first
team of the Middle Atlantic
Conference.
• • •

of the team's future performances.
Meet Line-up
The 400 yard medley relay,
the first event of the meet, figures to be a tight race. Kirk
Fry, captain Rich Tomasulo,
Noel Burnham and Howie Chernick will swim for Hopkins in
the relay. Chernick will also
race the 200 yard butterfly and
swim a leg of the freestyle relay as well,
Al Henry will take care of the
freestyle sprints, while Tomasulo
will handle the 200-yard breaststroke. Sophomore Josh Treem
has been looking strong in the
individual medley and is expected to enter that race against the
Garnets.
Hopkins is also strong in diving with veteran Gene Linfors
and soph Rick Wilson. The duo
should give Hopkins its biggest
boost tomorrow. The meet should
be close, according to Klarner,
who expects a large crowd on
hand at the pool tomorrow.
Action Expected

Hopkins will host two championship meets this winter. At
the end of February, the Maryland State High School Championships will be held at the
Hopkins pool, The next week will
have the Middle Atlantic ConChampionships at Hopference
Sophomore end Steve Latson
was selected to the team all- kins, featuring powerhouse teams
Mason Dixon football team last from schools like Bucknell and
LaSalle.
week.

Two substitutes, 6-0 sophomore defensive specialist. John
Stott and 6-4 reserve center Ross
Krum, complement the Gettysburg starting array.
Gettysburg showed "good balance, good running ability, and
an aggressive defense" against
Western Maryland, according to
Hopkins scouting reports.
On the basis of the Jays' 74-60
loss to Gettysburg a year ago,
the influx of good Bullet sophs,
and the rougher opposition the
Pennsylvania squad has encountered, the current three-game
Hopkins win streak is in danger
of coming to a sharp halt tonight.
Jay coach Henry Ciccarone

noted the problems ahead but
remarked that his group could
pull an upset by "outhustling,
outrebounding , and outdefendMg" Gettysburg. He added that
on a man-to-man matchup, the
Jays are not lacking much.
Comparative Scores
The predictive usefulness of
comparative scores was put into
lower repute than ever last Saturday, when Swarthmore, bombed
by Dickinson (a fifteen point
loser to Lebanon Valley, which in
turn fell to the Jays 82-63) and
winless on the year, pushed Hopkins into overtime before falling

67-66. In the process, the Garnet
displayed a big surprise in 6-3,
210 soph center Dave Kamen,
who scored 21 points, pulled
down fifteen rebounds, and generally terrorized the Jay front
line.
The hoopsters, connecting on
only 35 per cent of their shots,
was saved twice by junior guard
Mike Sullivan, who hit the tying
basket in regulation play and an
overtime free throw that eventually proved to be the margin of
victory.
In addition to their difficulties

By JIM SLOAN
Assistant Sports Editor
While waiting for the varsity
basketball team to prove its first
three victories were no fluke, I
note that Bob Scott's lacrosse
squad, following the lead of
other national powers such as
Navy, Army, and Virginia, has
held organized off-season practices for the first time since
1948.
The stickers met before classes
began for an organizational
meeting and formally began fall
practice on October 3. Sessions
ran for six weeks with practices
every other day.
Objectives Accomplished
On Mondays and Wednesdays
co-captains Bill Deitrich and
Jerry Schnydman led the squad
in conditioning and stick work
exercises. The Friday meetings

were coached by Henry Ciccarone and Buzzy Budnitz, a former Mount Washington standout,
Half-field scrimmages were the
main business of these sessions.
The fall program was climaxed
with an informal scrimmage
with Baltimore University, and
it was concluded on November
11. The main objectives were accomplished—to coordinate the
team offense, to build a solid
team morale, and to afford a solid program of physical conditioning. Coach Scott was well
pleased with the results of the
practice sessions and considered
it a great success.

BIA Notes

Fraternity Fives Collide
With the first basketball games
played on Monday night, the
Board of Intramural Athletics
officially opened its winter season.
The number of games played
this year in each league is fewer
than any previous year because
of the expanded home schedule
for intercollegiate competition.
Whenever there is a varsity contest in the gym, the facilities
cannot be used for intramurals.
B-Ball Teams
Fraternity league "A" consists
of: Phi Psi, Phi Ep, Phi Gam,
Phi Sig, KA, AD. "B" league
consists of: ATO, Beta, DU,
AEPi, Sig Ep, TEP, ZBT.
In the Monday games in "A"
Phi Psi was edged by Phi Ep,
Phi Sig downed AD, and Phi
Gain trounced KA. In "B" competition ATO downed ZBT, DU
defeated AEPi, and Beta ran
over Sig Ep•
Swim Meet
The finals of the B.I.A. swim
meet were held last Saturday

(Continued on Page 9)

with the freshman dominating
the overall competition.
In the fraternity division, Phi
Gain took first place trailed by
Beta and Phi Sig. Griffin easily
won first place in the freshman
houses followed by Clark and
Baker. Wood defeated Willard
in upperclass dorm competition.
The freshmen showed their
swimming prowess by leading in
almost every event. Individual
event winners were: Bonnet
(50 yd. freestyle), Sealy (50 yd.
butterfly), Hannemenn (50 yd.
backstroke), Lowe (50 yd. breaststroke), Ware (100 yd. freestyle),
Trejida (100 yd. backstroke),
Turner (100 yd. breaststroke),
Ware (100 yd. ind. medley), Griffin house (200 yd. medley relay),
Griffin house (200 yd. freestyle
relay).
Post-Vacation
Coining up after vacation and
in the early part of the second
semester are several of the
B.I.A.'s minor sports. These will
include squash, handball, ping
pong, volleyball, and bowling.

Winter Workouts
Head coach Bob Scott, determined not to allow the physical
condition of his team to slump
during the winter months, has
with the aid of assistant Alex Sotir, instituted an organized eight
Week indoor plan for fitness
training. On Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays the football,
soccer, and lacrosse team members report to the gym for a
series of about fifteen exercises
including push ups, sit ups, rope
jumping, chin ups, and curls.
These exercises are divided into four classes—casual, physical
education, physical fitness, and
intercollegiate. These divisions
make it possible for persons of
any physical state to go through
the hour-long training course,
An example of this system is the
stair climb which requires the
Intercollegiate team members to
climb and descend a flight of
stairs 45 times, while casual participants do only seven repetitions.
• •
Congratulations
to
Hank
Kaestner, who was presented the
Schmeisser Award as the country's outstanding lacrosse defenseman this weekend in New
York. Also congrats to All-American midfielder, Jerry Schnydmars who will ????.
Condolences to Colonel Robert
Serena on the death of his longtime friend and companion,
Biggy.

Forum To
Academic
Students, faculty, and administration are scheduled to meet
next Tuesday in a forum sponsored by the Academic Affairs
Committee of the Student Council. The forum, which will begin
at 4 p.m. in the Garrett Room
of the Eisenhower Library, will
be open to all members of the
Hopkins academic community.
The forum is to be held for
the purpose of evaluating the
progress of the Administration
in responding to the Report of
the Undergraduate Committee
for Curriculum Studies, submitted last spring by undergraduates Robert Bittick and Robert
Butler. The report dealt in
length with the issues of departmental autonomy, course offerings, basic degree requirements,
faculty teaching, and the advising system.
Administration Response
As a direct result of suggestions made in the report, the
position of Dean of Undergraduate Studies was formed. As the
next step, a major increase in
faculty is planned, beginning
possibly next semester, to provide for a greater selection of
ccsirses. With this accomplished,
a plan to liberalize degree requirements will be instituted to
permit breadth as well as depth
In studies.

History Course on
Jobs Availa5le
'eview
American Negro
Policy To Be Offered
For Work-Study

Among those members of the
faculty and administration who
will serve on the forum panel
are Robert Strider, Associate
Dean for Administration, Dr.
Carl Swanson, Assistant Dean
for Undergraduate Studies, and
Dr. Stephen Ambrose, associate
professor of history. Bittick and
Butler will act as student representatives on the panel.
Action and Reaction
Butler will open the forum
with a statement summarizing
the report's goals, after which
Dean Swanson will explain what
action has been taken thus far.
Following Dean Swanson's remarks, other members of the
panel will be invited to speak,
after which will ensue a general
discussion period.
According to Mark Steinberg,
a junior student council representative and a member of its
Academic Affairs Committee, the
forum is the first of Several to
be held this year. Future discussions may center on such
topics as calendar reform, passfail grading, and a tutorial program. The success of the open
forum and its future use, he indicated, will depend largely on
the turn-out of the students, for
whose benefit it is being held.

Choral Society Bills
Mozart for Premier
Mozart's Requiem of 1791 and
the 30th Ode of Solomon by
American composer Alan Hoyhaness will open the Hopkins
Choral Society's second season
of concerts.
The works will be performed
on Sunday, January 8, at 3:30
p.m. in Shriver Hall.
Admission to the concert directed by Nelson Sweglar is free
and open to the entire public
through the financial assistance
of the Musical Performance
Trust Fund.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 16, 1966

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

The Department of History
will offer a course in Negro History during the second semester.
The course, entitled "The Negro
in America", will be taught by
Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick,
member of the faculty of Coppin State College in Baltimore.
According to Dr. Reddick, the
course will start with an African
background . and move to the
present. There will be special
emphasis on the aspects of Negro
History that have influenced the
growth of the American Republic, The point of view will be
economic, political, and cultural.
The course is presently scheduled for Thursday at 9-11 with
a conference hour to be included. In addition, it will probably
be limited to advanced undergraduates and graduates.

Forum Letter
Among the rumors floating around concerning the
University's new president, there is the one which claims
that his experience and future efforts will be found to
lie primarily in the academic sphere of education. With
the completion of a successful, if aesthetically unnerving,
building program under Dr. Eisenhower, the argument
runs, it is now time to focus on the essential justification
for the expanded physical plant, namely, the quality of
education at Hopkins.
Whether or not the new president will, in fact, be
oriented in this direction, the rumor is symptomatic
of a frame of mind which does presently exist among
iidministration and faculty. Plans to increase faculty,
offer more courses, and broaden degree requirements
&re major innovations long needed and soon to be
effected. In passing, we might note that unfortunate rejection by the Academic Council of any sort of pass-fail
grading system.
The forum next Tuesday will give undergraduates
die opportunity to question the powers that he concerning these plans, and the chance to voice whatever
dissatisfactions they may have with the current system.
To this end, we hope that members of the forum panel
other than the principal speakers will keep their comments brief, as with not the case at the last such
gathering.

THE DECLINE AND FALL
By ELIA KATZ
Now that it is Friday and in
two days the Baltimore Civic
Center is giving us THE BIG
BIG SOUL SHOW, and we will
all (I hope to God, all) all be
there to see: THE TEMPTATATIONS! cyns! REDDING!
and MARTHA & THE V.D's! it
seems a good time to reflect upon
the state of popular music and
to draw some pertinent relationships between it (the state of
that) to society. American society in the larger, ugly sense,
Which are, in short, that one is
the microcosm and one is the
macrocosm of the same set of
phenomena, which phenomena
all point to the fact that the
white race, now weak and fleshy
with sloth and money, is no
longer of use to Nature and is
about to be done away with. Extinguished. We are witnessing
the Decline, soon to be the Fall,
of the pink people.
Listen to the radio. Compare
WCAO (where Pat Boone and
Frank Sinatra reside) to WWIN
(the Home of Soul) and tell me
how we can survive. (We, I being
white). Can a race that snaps
its fingers to STRANGERS IN
THE NIGHT compare to one
that goes epileptic to READY
FOR LOVE by Martha and the
girls? Don't be rediculous, Where
is the vitality, the throbbing
life, of LADY GODIVA by that
(some) English group, or Herman's Hermits. You can't build

a culture on novelty songs! Or
on advertisements—notice that
WCAO plays approx. 6 songs an
hour. This is no accident. The
people who listen to it don't
mind. They don't care about the
intensity of emotion or the galvanizing effect upon the body of
DRUMS — those people want
background sound, Muzac, something to obliterate thought as
they walk around the house
dusting, or travel from chair to
chair in the day's odyssey to bed.
They don't want to feel good,
they just want to feel full, and
they take the radio in like potatoes, for filling that's cheap and
easy. I mean does anybody
listen to WINCHESTER CATHEDRAL? How long are they
going to simper into your ears,
white America? (call to action:
there'll be dancin indo streets,
as Martha and the V's say), simper, simper go the Chesapeake
Rug and Drapery Ads, and the
singing bank ads and the rhyming loan company ads.
The Viet Nam war. Now, here's
a point of comparison. When a
society involves itself in a tremendous, earthshaking and universally important action, all
levels of that society are concerned, and they consequently
attempt to deal with the aspects
of that action which most affect
them in those forms of art and
communication which most occupy them. Ergo: America deals
with Viet Nam on the radio—
in rock and roll. But how?
Which attitude suggests more
realistic (survivalistic) attitudes,
Pat Boone'a opus (name of

5eCr.'47Alt-

which I forget) that makes fun
of people who oppose the wax
on the grounds that those people
have long hair—which, I suppose, Pat Boone can document.
Or those beautiful, beautiful Negro songs about people who (1)
don't want to go to war and
leave their baby (2) want to get
back from the war and return to,
their baby
Those people have
more than drums and rhythm,
they have the love and life instincts. They have the sense to
know when they are being
dumped upon.
So. (I'll be lookin' to see your
face inda place, your feet onda
seats, anda smile on your face
as you walk down duh aisle. An'
see the last big souls show for
sixty-six, Baby!) Remember,
Baby. Temptations, Martha, Otis
Redding, Lee Dorsey (who does
HOLY COW) and maybe best of
all, Lorraine Ellison, who is fantastic, who has found the way to
fit a tune to the human scream
mechanism. And the audience
will lift itself off its collective
behind and, (probably, I don't
promise, but probably) destroy
the Civic Center—rip the chairs
out and knife the white people.
Dancing will graduate to spasm,
excitement will cross the bound
into hysteria, You should be
there if you can, because you will
learn something about the great
big UPANDCOMIN' SUBCULTURE, boobyluh. You'll wonder,
as we all have, how these strong _
and healthy, young and sweating Negroes managed to get a
4F and stay out of the Army.
Brains, baby, brains!

Wyeth Defies Criticism
tyllyeth Belies Belief
By PETER KOPER
Andrew Wyeth is out of it. Museum
Curators, art critics, and art students—
the dictators of our modern mass culture — tell us that he has received the
death sentence for artists; he is not
in the mainstream of the modern art
movement.
The hip among the art followers don't
dig him. He's old. And worst of all he
is nostalgic, almost historical.
And look at his pictures. He really
Is out of it. Sam Hunter, a professor
of art and spokesman for the New York
school of art, or what is called the
Abstract Expressionist movement, tells
116 that "in. view of the achievements
Of the Abstract Expressionists in the
fifties it is no longer possible to assume
that the opposing currents of realism,

ularly pails, houses, shacks, fences,
weeds, grass, boats, his wife, the surrounding neighbors, dogs, and snowstorms. He attacks his limited world
with the gusto of a Thomas Wolfe with
blinders. "The wealth of things around
us for an artist to see is just unbelievable. To see it and clarify it in my own
mind. That is the thing," Wyeth comments on his choice of subjects.
And, indeed, this is the key to his
approach, to his philosophy, to his
art, and to his attraction of an admiring public. Wyeth simply paints and
simply lives. His painting forces the
intensificiation of common objects to the
point of realizing that they are a part
of him. He lives his paintings.
Existential Virtue
Existential virtue, That is what his
art is. He describes the existence of an
object and then derives its essence.
"All I know is that I'm not a realist
at all," claims Wyeth, trying to escape
the tag placed on him by the taxonomists of art. And he isn't. If anything
he is an abstract painter, chiefly because of the strength of his compositions. Take a look at That Gentleman,
or Racoon, or even Christina's World.
Asymetrical design and balanced focus,
space and clutter.
Colors Noted
His paintings conjure up the ghosts
of Winslow Homer or John Singer Sergeant or Frederick Remington. But look
at his colors. For the wide range of
tone contrasted with the limited scale
of hue he can be compared with Titian
or Bellini. His use of a low key in
his paintings can be seen in the Potato
Eaters by Van Gogh or The Studio by
Daumier. Anybody can play this game.

'

In one picture, The Children's Doctor,
a portrait of a Johns Hopkins graduate,
he is a surrealist. As a matter of fact
one could compare it favorably with
Dail's Gala. Her Room is another of
Wyeth's creations which makes you
wonder whether he ever fooled with
LSD.

CHRISTINA'S WORLD
ings in Wyeth's reportoire also.
Distant Thunder is a good example of a daydream Tom Sawyer
existence that prays on everybody's
mind. The Coot Hunter is another good
example of a full, robust feeling of life.
This picture is a good example of
Wyeth's earlier period of undisciplined
watercolor. He turned to the dry brush
technique and produced His Boot and
Faraway which sharpened his perspective.
After his father, an illustrator of
books, died in 1945, Wyeth turned introspective and developed his low key
approach. Many see this as sadness in
his paintings. The mood best expressed
in this stage of his painting is Winter
1946. It also marks the maturation of
his egg tempera technique. Egg tempera
he picked up from his then future
brother-in-law Peter Hurd, a noted New
Mexico landscape painter. This technique, it must be explained, uses min-

center around brown or black against
white. The Bachelor is a good example
of this. The painting is merely a white
shirt hanging on a porch, but the effect
of the white cloth coining out of the
shadow of the interior of the porch is
stunning.

Look at the man and you will see

country, never went to school, and never

Greenwich Village atmosphere in
a hostile world. No wonder he's not

two places — Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania and Cushing, Maine. In the summer he stays in Maine, and in the
winter he stays in Pennsylvania, where
he was born. And worst of all, he paints
tinly what he is familiar with in these
two places. "This is all I have room for
in my heart," states Wyeth simply
enough.
Simple Things
Wyeth is a fanatic on the simple
things he sees around him — partic-

in
Where Wyeth really shines
snowstorms. He paints with such freedom that Jackson Pollock may have
been jealous. In the Mill, March Storm,
or River Valley the paint flies with the
best of the action painters.
They say he is sad. One is left with
this impression when one looks at his
paintings. Christina's World, perhaps
the best known of his paintings, is a
study in solitude. Christina's World, by
the way, was pulled out of the current
exhibition at the Baltimore Museum of Art in Philadelphia by the
Museum of Modern Art to placate its
New York customers. Her Room is sad
too. Very quiet and very deserted.
Wyeth claims that this disturbs people,
that silence and solitude is unknown
to a great many citizens of the urban
carnivals.
Painting Memories
Memories, however, are quiet things
that live in another conciousness. And
one gets the feeling that Wyeth is
painting memories. Brief flash cards in
the cranium. "I agree with Pollock,
and Kline, and de Kooning that there
must be complete freedom. But they
lack the object. I'd like to paint the
thing just as it might happen to look
as you walk by. I don't mean a snapshot; it's more than just a glimpse,"
says Wyeth of his paintings.
There are good day sunshine paint-

In his landscapes, Wyeth uses a style
of focusing his object. Sharp and clear
and naturalistic is his object, but as
the scene fades into grass or snow, one
is aware of a fuzziness that overtakes
the entire foreground. His texture is
all a matter of perspective. When you
go to see his exhibit at the Baltimore
Museum of Art, don't stand too close
at first. Come at each of his paintings
at a distance, and then move in for a
closer examination. Rather than layering his paint, he deals a great part,of
the time with shadows and perspective,
creating his magic textures painstakingily.
Wyeth's colors do their work in
creating the mood and shading of the
painting. Very few wild contrasts will

Andrew Wyeth draws his subjects from
four square miles of Pennsylvania and

the summer he is instantaneously transported from Chadds Ford to Cushing. In
the winter back to Chadds Ford. He has
never been anywhere else. As a result,

capture a sharper view of time and
sequence.
It is mood that concerns Wyeth, not
tone, as the Impressionists sought, nor
realism, which everyone scorns. Wyeth
takes a moment, reacts to it many
times, and uses highly skilled methods
to translate through intensification that
moment. This is not illustration; it is
skilled perception and interpretation.

Dorm Rules
Colonel J. Robert Serena, Head
Resident Counselor of the dormitories, announced last week that
the rule requiring that the door
must remain open at least 450
when one couple is in the room
in the upperclass dorms had
been rescinded by Dean of Students, William K. Morrill.
The ruling will henceforth require that the door be kept open
at a "discretionary distance." It
applies to upperclass dorm residents only.
This discretionary distance
will be left up to the presidents
of the various upperclass dorms,
but it has been made very clear
for the residents that post cards
Will not be allowed.
The new policy is a return to
the way the ruling had read in
years prior to 1965-66. It is
hoped that this will encourage
students to live in the dormitories rather than off campus facilities.

'TIS THE SEASON TO BE JOLLY
I know how busy you are—studying,going to class,helping old grads find their dentures after Homecoming—but,
hark, the Yuletide is almost upon us and it's time we
turned our thoughts to Christmas shopping.
We'll start with the hardest gift problem of all: what to
give the man who has everything. Well sir, here are some
things I'll bet he doesn't have: 1) A dentist's chair. 2) A
Mach number. 3) A street map of Perth, Australia. 4)
Fifty pounds of chicken fat. 5) A pack of Personna Super
Stainless Steel Blades.
"What?" you exclaim, your eyebrows leaping in wild
incredulity. "The man who has everything doesn't have
Personna Super Stainless Steel Blades? What arrant nonsense!" you scoff, making a coarse gesture.
But I insist. The man who has everything doesn't have
Personna because everyone in the dorm is always borrowing them. And small wonder! Wouldn't you be there with
an empty razor and a supplicating sidle if you heard somebody had super-blades that were super-sharp and superdurable; that scrape not, neither do they nick; that shave
you easily and breezily, quickly and slickly, scratchlessly
and matchlessly; that come both in Double-Edge style and
Injector style? Of course you would!
So here is our first gift suggestion. If you know a man
who shaves with Personna, give him a safe.
Next let us take up the thorny problem of buying gifts
when you have no money. Well sir, there are many wonderful gifts which cost hardly anything. A bottle of good
clear water,for example,is always welcome. A nice smooth
rock makes a charming paperweight. In fact, one Christmas back in my own college days, these are exactly the
gifts I gave a beauteous coed named Norma Glebe. I took
a rock, a bottle of water, a bit of ribbon, and attached a
card with this tender sentiment:
Here's some water
And here's a rock.
I love you,daughter,
Around the clock.
Norma was so moved, she seized the rock, smashed the
bottle, and plunged the jagged edge into my sternum.

Here now is a lovely gift for an American History major
—a bronze statuette of Millard Fillmore with a clock in
the stomach. (Mr. Fillmore, incidentally, was the only
American president with a clock in his stomach. James K.
Polk had a stem-winder in his head and William Henry
Harrison chimed the quarter-hour, but only Mr. Fillmore
of all our chief executives had a clock in his stomach.
Franklin Pierce had a sweep second hand and Zachary
Taylor had 17 jewels and Martin Van Buren ticked but, I
repeat, Mr. Fillmore and Mr. Fillmore alone had a clock
in his stomach. Moreover,Mr.Fillmore was the first president with power steering. No wonder they called him
"Old Hickory!")
But I digress. Returning to Christmas gifts, here's one
that's sure to please—a gift certificate from the American
Society of Chiropractors. Accompanying each certificate
is this fetching little poem:
Merry Christmas, Happy New Year,
Joyous sacro-iliac!
May your spine forever shine,
Blessings on your aching back!
May your lumbar ne'er grow number,
May your backbone ne'er dislodge,
May your caudal never dawdle,
Joyeux Noel! Heureux massage!
* * *

Nearly nailed by Swarthmore
last Saturday, the varsity basketball team meets its toughest foe
so far at 8:30 tonight when
Gettysburg invades the Newton
H. White Athletic Center for the
Jays final pre-Christmas game.
The Bullets have lost to Albright and nationally-ranked LaSalle by 68-58 and 103-67 counts,
but have subdued Western Maryland 71-50. Competing in the

usually schedule tougher opposition than does Hopkins.
The Jays who have not beaten
Gettysburg since 1952, are tonight trying to halt a fourteen
game losing streak to tonight's
visitors.
Pacing the Pennsylvania team
in scoring are its two guards,
6-0 senior Steve Satir and 5-10
junior, Rick Falk, who hit for 20
and 18 points respectively in the
Western Maryland contest.
A rugged front line consisting
of 6-5 senior captain Ray Faczan
and two upcomers from '65-66's
18-3 frosh team, 6-2 Tom Houser
and 6-3 Paul Trojak, provides the
Bullets with plenty of board
strength and is likely to be their
big advantage over Hopkins.

In addition to their difficulties

By JIM SLOAN
Assistant Sports Editor
While waiting for the varsity
basketball team to prove its first
three victories were no fluke, I
note that Bob Scott's lacrosse
squad, following the lead of
other national powers such as
Navy, Army, and Virginia, has
held organized off-season practices for the first time since
1948.
The stickers met before classes
began for an organizational
meeting and formally began fall
practice on October 3. Sessions
ran for six weeks with practices
every other day.
Objectives Accomplished
On Mondays and Wednesdays
co-captains Bill Deitrich and
Jerry Schnydman led the squad
in conditioning and stick work
exercises. The Friday meetings

were coached by Henry Ciccarone and Buzzy Budnitz, a former Mount Washington standout,
Half-field scrimmages were the
main business of these sessions.
The fall program was climaxed
with an informal scrimmage
with Baltimore University, and
it was concluded on November
11. The main objectives were accomplished—to coordinate the
team offense, to build a solid
team morale, and to afford a solid program of physical conditioning. Coach Scott was well
pleased with the results of the
practice sessions and considered
it a great success.

BIA Notes

Fraternity Fives Collide
With the first basketball games
played on Monday night, the
Board of Intramural Athletics
officially opened its winter season.
The number of games played
this year in each league is fewer
than any previous year because
of the expanded home schedule
for intercollegiate competition.
Whenever there is a varsity contest in the gym, the facilities
cannot be used for intramurals.
B-Ball Teams
Fraternity league "A" consists
of: Phi Psi, Phi Ep, Phi Gam,
Phi Sig, KA, AD. "B" league
consists of: ATO, Beta, DU,
AEPi, Sig Ep, TEP, ZBT.
In the Monday games in "A"
Phi Psi was edged by Phi Ep,
Phi Sig downed AD, and Phi
Gain trounced KA. In "B" competition ATO downed ZBT, DU
defeated AEPi, and Beta ran
over Sig Ep•
Swim Meet
The finals of the B.I.A. swim
meet were held last Saturday

(Continued on Page 9)

with the freshman dominating
the overall competition.
In the fraternity division, Phi
Gain took first place trailed by
Beta and Phi Sig. Griffin easily
won first place in the freshman
houses followed by Clark and
Baker. Wood defeated Willard
in upperclass dorm competition.
The freshmen showed their
swimming prowess by leading in
almost every event. Individual
event winners were: Bonnet
(50 yd. freestyle), Sealy (50 yd.
butterfly), Hannemenn (50 yd.
backstroke), Lowe (50 yd. breaststroke), Ware (100 yd. freestyle),
Trejida (100 yd. backstroke),
Turner (100 yd. breaststroke),
Ware (100 yd. ind. medley), Griffin house (200 yd. medley relay),
Griffin house (200 yd. freestyle
relay).
Post-Vacation
Coining up after vacation and
in the early part of the second
semester are several of the
B.I.A.'s minor sports. These will
include squash, handball, ping
pong, volleyball, and bowling.

Winter Workouts
Head coach Bob Scott, determined not to allow the physical
condition of his team to slump
during the winter months, has
with the aid of assistant Alex Sotir, instituted an organized eight
Week indoor plan for fitness
training. On Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays the football,
soccer, and lacrosse team members report to the gym for a
series of about fifteen exercises
including push ups, sit ups, rope
jumping, chin ups, and curls.
These exercises are divided into four classes—casual, physical
education, physical fitness, and
intercollegiate. These divisions
make it possible for persons of
any physical state to go through
the hour-long training course,
An example of this system is the
stair climb which requires the
Intercollegiate team members to
climb and descend a flight of
stairs 45 times, while casual participants do only seven repetitions.
